Dear queer* people, please never stop writing.

Maia Kobabe's memoir (e/em/eir) is an enlightening addition to literature on the nonbinary experience, especially written by someone assigned female at birth (afab) - I do not own that many books like this. Started as a way to explain to eir family what it means to be nonbinary and asexual,¬†the book is more than a personal story: it is a useful and touching guide on gender identity - what it means and how to think about it - for advocates, friends, and humans everywhere.

The way the story is told took some getting used to as it did not flow as I usually prefer, feeling almost stream of consciousness-y at times in the way that e jumps from one point of the eir life to the next depending on the memory linked to the story being presently told.

Gender Queer reads as real as queer nonfiction can get, and that‚Äôs the part that makes the book all the more important - it provides information that most young people going through this stuff can not find elsewhere but the internet, which is a dangerous place. Kobabe gifts us with eir experiences, and we get to feel what e feels because the brutally honest depictions aren‚Äôt there to serve as graphic trauma porn but an experience. We feel it all - the confusion, dissatisfaction, questioning, the dysphoria. I appreciated how we were able to be invited into most of these defining moments in eir journey of discovery; like trying to understand teenage crushes, buying and trying out sex toys and how mortified and traumatised e felt during eir first pap smear - something they define as having been invasive, bearing psychological scarring.

As an enby reader, reading about a journey of coming to claim one‚Äôs own identity in spite of society‚Äôs need to define you and coming out victorious in such a sense that you become empowered to write your own story how you see fit; quotes like ‚ÄúI want people to be confused about my gender at all times.‚Äù and ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want MORE gendered traits, I want LESS.‚Äù hit home and made me feel understood, something every queer person should get to feel. 

This is such a great resource.

GENDER QUEER by Maia Kobabe

In 2014, Maia Kobabe, who uses e/em/eir pronouns, thought that a comic of reading statistics would be the last autobiographical comic e would ever write. At the time, it was the only thing e felt comfortable with strangers knowing about em. Now, Gender Queer is here. Maia's intensely cathartic autobiography charts eir journey of self-identity, which includes the mortification and confusion of adolescent crushes, grappling with how to come out to family and society, bonding with friends over erotic gay fanfiction, and facing the trauma of pap smears. Started as a way to explain to eir family what it means to be nonbinary and asexual, Gender Queer is more than a personal story: it is a useful and touching guide on gender identity--what it means and how to think about it--for advocates, friends, and humans everywhere. 

~~~~~~~~~~~

‚ÄúI began to think of gender less as a scale and more of a landscape‚Ä¶. Some people are happy to live in a place they were born, while others must make a journey to reach the climate in which they can flourish and grow.‚Äù

~~~~~~~~~~

I think every person who aspires to be a trans ally needs to read this book. It‚Äôs raw and real and I found myself laughing and teary throughout. Maia and I do not share the same gender identity, but I related to so much of eir experiences. 

This book is one of the most banned books in the country right now, and Virginia is currently suing Kobabe and eir publisher over it‚Äîthis is scary, because we need books like this in order to learn and see ourselves. So GO READ THIS BOOK. The deluxe edition releases in a few days, so this is a perfect time to go preorder it!

~~~~~~~~~~

Banned books. My feelings on this week are so muddled, and my time in libraries, only opened more complex feelings. 

I only recently read Maus. It was my oldest brother's favorite book growing up, and we hated each other, and per sibling code, *I* couldn't also read it and enjoy it, too. 

It's not an easy book, and it surprised me by opening many questions on generational trauma, survivor's guilt, and navigating relationships through PTSD. I always appreciate a book that leaves you with more questions than answers.

Why is it banned? Nudity and swearing, is the most common reason. Nudity. Of an approximate one inch crude mouse drawing. Way to miss the whole fucking point.

Gender Queer. We've all heard it get cited in multiple bans this past year. And by cited, I mean a singular panel, pulled out of context and paraded around, as though they care about children.

If they cared, they'd read the book, and see in the blow job panel they use is a strap on, and are in the middle of a very important discussion involving consent and autonomy. It gives teens the example of, even in the middle of any sexual activity, consent can be revoked.

I wish nothing but terrible things on the people currently on their crusade against queer books.

I finished reading @redgoldsparks Gender Queer the other day and it was really incredible. I don't think there's anything out there quite like it right now, and there certainly wasn't while I was growing up. My wife and I recently moved from one of the most liberal cities in our state to someplace more typically midwest. There's a lot of conservative political signs here... A few of those red hats... And like seriously just white people. But I found this book at the local library and I felt a tiny bit better. I had forgotten how books can be a lifeline. I hope other queer people in this town and other towns like it all over the country can find books like this and see themselves reflected back in the pages and find a little comfort

Friends. Friends. Do you ever read a book that leaves you fully speechless? Like. You read it, and it reached down into your heart and squeezed and made you feel so many things that you don‚Äôt even know how to find the language to describe the feeling? This. This book did that for me. 

I have almost nothing in common with Maia Kobabe. I am cis, a sexual being, and not even remotely artistic. Maia is genderqueer, asexual, and deeply talented artistically, as is evident by this incredible art. But, somehow, I felt connected to eir story in a way I haven‚Äôt in a long time. I‚Äôm not sure if it was eir‚Äôs beautiful way of describing eir journey with gender and sexuality through books and art or just the stunning storytelling, but this book was a revelation and a window and a deeply emotive experience. Thank you to everyone who recommended this to me this month and fully yelled at me for not reading it yet (seriously, HOW has it taken me so long to get to it???) I am so so grateful to this community for continuing to share and educate and spread love of good books! 

If you, like me, haven‚Äôt gotten to experience this one yet, I highly HIGHLY recommend picking it up ASAP.

Thoughts on Gender Queer by Maia Kobabe

My Quick Take: For those who think the freedom to read is important, the lawsuit against this book is important to be aware of. And it‚Äôs an excellent graphic novel! 
***
Thanks to @bookriot podcast for highlighting this issue! 

I‚Äôll direct you to my blog for my detailed thoughts about the book and the suit. I go into greater depth and I hope you‚Äôll find it useful to get information and perhaps interested enough to pick up the book: 
https://www.trishtalksbooks.com/2022/07/a-very-challenged-book-review-and.html

I‚Äôve pulled from my blog entry, and included a quote from the author in the pictures here. 

Gender Queer is charged in Virginia for being ‚Äúobscene for unrestricted viewing for minors‚Äù at a Barnes & Noble outlet. For fans of Sarah J. Maas (and I know that there are A LOT of you in BG land!) the other book in the lawsuit is A Court of Mist and Fury, which I‚Äôve not read.The litigants then filed charges against Maia Kobabe and @onipress . 

My response to this was to read the book. Kobabe (redgoldsparks), who uses the Spivak pronouns e/er/eir, has written er memoir as a graphic novel. I thought it was really good, thoughtful and also educational for me. It was an amazing example of an open, honest memoir. The art made the author‚Äôs struggle come alive on the page; the visuals were an integral part of the novel. It is simply and effectively coloured by @phoebekobabe.psd. Be aware: It didn‚Äôt shy away from uncomfortable and explicit discussion and art , but in my opinion, it all served the story. It‚Äôs not a book intended for youngsters, but was written for older teens and adults specifically. 

Most think the suit will fail. The agenda here may be an attempt to garner publicly and capture right-leaning votes. But it is alarming nonetheless. And in Canada? It could never happen‚Ä¶but I don‚Äôt know. Things change, and a bit of vigilance is not a bad thing.

I‚Äôm curious: Were you aware of this lawsuit, for either Gender Queer or A Court of Mist and Fury? If you‚Äôve read them, what are your thoughts?

Another book review!

I first heard of Maia Kobabe‚Äôs ‚ÄúGender Queer‚Äù because bigoted christians were trying to ban it.

And it‚Äôs also a book about being gender queer (and ace!), and a *graphic memoir* at that. So of course I had to buy myself a copy.

I laughed, I cried, and I felt so *seen* by this book, in a way that I, as an afab nonbinary person, rarely experience. (Note that Kobabe‚Äôs experience as a nonbinary person is not the same as mine, nor anyone else‚Äôs but Kobabe‚Äôs; however, there are plenty of similarities and points of resonance between some of what I felt & experienced and some of what e did. And some of what e wrote helped me better understand myself‚Äîlike why I also suddenly hated being in pictures once I hit puberty.)

This memoir, so vulnerable and real, reflects how difficult, confusing, and at times isolating it is to come out to yourself (and others) as queer. Kobabe was raised in a fairly progressive, dare I even say slightly hippie kind of family, but e still experienced a lot of anxiety around coming out as nonbinary. In the book, e even includes a scene about a feminist aunt who accused em of being nonbinary solely because e had internatlized misogyny (which is not why afab people are nonbinary!).

Unfortunatley we live in a sh*tty world where we have to fight for the ability to be ourselves and live in peace. And it's hard and scary and intimidating, but it's so comforting to know that there is a community that exists to welcome us with open arms‚Äîa community with some of its own issues and bigotry to overcome, yes, but a place where overall, dialogue and freedom and authenticity are celebrated. And I love how many creative queer people are sharing their stories and experiences, letting struggling or scared queer people know that we're not alone.

So anyway. I highly recommend this graphic novel, whether you‚Äôre trans or not.

And I‚Äôm so, so glad this book exists.

At the beginning of the month, a school board in Utah decided they were going to ban 52 books from their libraries.¬† They've received backlash and criticism and, so, as of 11 August, it appears they've decided they will only be "temporarily restricting" these books where parents can opt-in to allow their children to check them out.¬† 

https://pen.org/press-release/ban-on-52-books-in-largest-utah-school-district-is-a-worrisome-escalation-of-censorship/

Regardless of their change of heart, this is yet another example lately of book banning.¬† These actions infuriate me.¬† These people who decide to ban books are trying to silence people who aren't like them or who tell a story about teenagers being teenagers (ex: Forever by Judy Blume).¬† Kids need to be able to read about someone who has the same life experiences they do.¬† Life is hard.¬† It's not fair.¬† I learned that from books...and from life.¬† As a child, my mother did not censor my books at all.¬† The Happy Hooker, fine.¬† It (at age 12), fine.¬† The song "Shout at the Devil" by Motley Crue?¬† Absolutely not!¬† (But that's another story).¬† 

For the rest of the year, I'm going to choose 1 banned book a month and give it a read, or a re-read.¬† I'll start with one of the most controversial, Gender Queer.¬† Spoiler alert: I've already read this so this will be a re-read.¬† I'll get off my soapbox, for now, but this is a subject I'm passionate about.¬†

In this memoir told through a graphic novel, Maia Kobabe (e/em/eir) shares about eir discovery of gender identity in general and ultimately eir own gender identity awakening. Maia takes us through eir childhood, adolescence, first crushes, milestones, all while trying to figure out not only where e belongs in the world but also where e belongs in eir own space. I‚Äôve read coming of age and coming of identity narratives before, but this one felt different. The understandings and explanations Maia gave felt new and very forgiving (of eirself and of others). I found reflections like this one profound: ‚ú®‚ÄúSome people are born in the mountains, while others are born by the sea. Some people are happy to live in the place they were born, while others must make a journey to reach the climate in which they can flourish and grow. Between the ocean and the mountains is a wild forest. That is where I want to make my home.‚Äù

I‚Äôm going through a little comic book/graphic novel phase. It started when I discovered the Ms Marvel comics (more on that coming later) and found myself in a comic book store and realized how broad and diverse this format has become. I saw this book, flipped through a few pages, and was so excited to read more. A medium that is new to me, graphic novels are incredible. The author is able to relay so many more details with fewer words making it a pretty unique experience. If you are an avid graphic novel reader, I‚Äôm sure this sounds obvious but it was new to me and honestly I didn‚Äôt really know that it could be used to tell such a personal story. I am so late to the game and I am so glad I‚Äôm here now- it was really just a lot of fun to read and see all the graphics and details in the story telling and in the drawing. Format aside, this story itself was beautiful and captivating. 

‚ú®‚ÄúThe clearest metaphor I had for my own gender identity in college was the image of a scale. A huge weight had been placed on one side, without my permission. I was constantly trying to weigh down the other side. But the end goal wasn't masculinity - the goal was balance.‚Äù

After seeing that a Michigan library was defunded over this book I immediately went to my local bookstore to buy a copy to see for myself what it is about this book that is making people go completely INSANE.

After reading it, I still don't get it.

I don't want to make assumptions about  parents who want this book banned, however, as a parent, if my teenager came to me questioning their gender, I would recommend this book and then discuss it with them. 

I recommend this book, go borrow it from your local library or buy a copy from your local indie bookstore so that you can see for yourself!

I think we need to listen more to stories and life experiences that are not our own and then just sit with it. It is an important practice to do so. This is a graphic memoir about the author‚Äôs experiences with coming to understand eir gender identity. It‚Äôs a coming of age memoir that both informs and is beautifully drawn. There are some depictions of some difficult things including traumatic medical examinations, so be forewarned about that. This is a great one to pick up if you are interested in learning more about gender identity or if you simply love a good graphic memoir.

My last completed read for June was this memoir of Maia Kobabe's journey to understand and define eir sexuality. I found the simple direct honesty of the writing and the illustrations impactful and so deeply human. 

I've always used books to help me understand and process the world and my place in it. As the parent of a non-binary teen, it's important for me to understand the ways in which even those of us parents who are supportive can unintentionally hurt our kids who are already facing so many challenges, as well as the ways we can support them as they find their way to joy. I also want to read as many different viewpoints as possible so I don't fall into the trap of thinking everyone's journey is the same. I was surprised when my kiddo showed up in a dress the other day, and had to remind myself that non-binary doesn't equal androgynous, even if that's how they usually choose to dress. 

I was shocked to read about the challenges the book and author have faced. (OK. Not shocked. I'm not that naive.) I wish more people would be open to reading about experiences different from their own and use those stories to humanize and empathize with others. Alas.

I‚Äôm not the only one?‚Äù Or I can read a memoir and see nothing of my lived experience. I can see a life different from mine but just as human‚Äîand what a precious opportunity that is. My preferred method of reading is physical paper copy but I had no such luxury for this book. The library system I work for decided to remove it from our physical collection after several members of the board made enough fuss about it. I do not know all the back and forth that transpired between board and administration before this call was made, but the decision stands that patrons cannot come into our building and check out this book. It no longer exists in our catalog. 
This choice not only has ripple effects and casts a foreboding shadow on future collection challenges, but it has immediate effects for myself, as a library professional who believes a public library should reflect the entire public, and for my non-binary, gender queer, and trans friends and coworkers. Is the library a safe space for them when books that reflect and affirm their humanity are challenged and removed from circulation?
